questions.text: Phishing is an act of obtaining the identity of a person in a fraudulent approach.
questions.explain_if_correct: Right on the spot!
questions.explain_if_wrong: That is actually true, phishing is actually an act done to steal someone's sensitive data in an illegal approach.

questions.text: Phishing is one of least recurrent cyber attacks, and least threatening.
questions.explain_if_correct: Right on the spot! It is actually one of most persistent and threatening cyberattacks.
questions.explain_if_wrong: This statement is false. Phishing is one of the most recurrent cyberattacks, posing a great threat to cyber security.

questions.text: Social Engineering techniques are not used in phishing attacks.
questions.explain_if_correct: Exactly! They're actually used, with the scope of manipulating the targets.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Not exactly true, these strategies are used to manipulate targets to give out essential credentials to phishers.

questions.text: Email is the main communication channel between business workers, and the most used phishing mechanism by attackers, that send emails with compromised links and attachments.
questions.explain_if_correct: Nice catch!
questions.explain_if_wrong: Business workers are actually using email as main communication channel, and phishers take advantage of this mechanism, sending phish emails with links and attachments.

questions.text: You get an email about a job application, which contains a link, with instructions to click on it immediately. Is this a legitimate email?
questions.explain_if_correct: Well done, that smells of...a phishing attempt, blended with social engineering tactics.
questions.explain_if_wrong: It's in fact not legitimate. If you ever get a email like this, pressuring you to click on something, disregard it immediately. These are the social engineering mechanism a phisher is using to manipulate you.

questions.text: Smishing stands for SMS messages, and Vishing for voice phishing, which includes phone calls and voice messages.
questions.explain_if_correct: Great job, that's the answer!
questions.explain_if_wrong: Smishing is a term used to describe phished SMS messages, while Vishing is for suspicious phone calls and voice messages a potential target receives.

questions.text: You have just received an SMS about a package that is on the way, however you're asked to fill out a form to receive the package. Is this phishing?
questions.explain_if_correct: That's what we call a great approach!
questions.explain_if_wrong: This strategy is used by the phisher to pressure you on giving away your credentials, so as a rule of thumb, it's always the best to ignore such messages.

questions.text: When you pick up the call, you get met by a robotic-like voice, saying 'We need to talk, text me.'. Is this phishing?
questions.explain_if_correct: Great job! This is, yet, another phishing attempt, with social engineering included.
questions.explain_if_wrong: If you ever get met by a robotic-like voice, you never proceed to respect the instructions or saying any word, as not only phishers are trying to steal your data, but also your voice to use it for other targets.

questions.text: There are barely any cases of email phishing.
questions.explain_if_correct: Right on the spot, email phishing is actually one of the most recurrent types of phishing.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Being given the email is a primary communication channel, this statement is false. It is also the most used type of phishing.

questions.text: Phishing is easy to identify.
questions.explain_if_correct: That's a great catch, not so easy to depict.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Not exactly, it is quite difficult to depict a phishing attempt if not properly educated on this matter.

questions.text: You have received an email from this sender, but something might be wrong with the domain.
questions.explain_if_correct: You got it right. Mismatched domain is a clear red flag.
questions.explain_if_wrong: The domain is mismatched, which indicates a big red flag, and possible phishing attempt.

questions.text: You have received this following email with a...great offer.
questions.explain_if_correct: Good catch! Unbelievable offers are a classic phishing trap.
questions.explain_if_wrong: You've been tricked by a unbelievable offer, a classic phishing tactic.

questions.text: Let's see what do you think about this domain...
questions.explain_if_correct: Exactly, that's a good one!
questions.explain_if_wrong: This is actually legitimate, no mismatched domain here.

questions.text: A suspicious activity? More like a suspicious email...
questions.explain_if_correct: PhisGotcha!
questions.explain_if_wrong: Typos in the link like v0ila, not voila, unsecured padlock, and 'activation', but not 'active' are clearly red flags.

questions.text: Here is a confirmation email about changing your email on a website. This one is tricky.
questions.explain_if_correct: It's legitimate! Despite the 'immediately' word, this is common to receive a confirmation like that.
questions.explain_if_wrong: If you changed your email, it is normal to get a confirmation for that, so this is safe.

questions.text: A campaign from your gym place. Let's see...
questions.explain_if_correct: Nice job, this is a safe one.
questions.explain_if_wrong: This is actually legitimate. Might seem unbelievable, but there are actually well-defined contest rules.

questions.text: Urgent email from your CEO? Let's check it out...
questions.explain_if_correct: An another phisher has been catched!
questions.explain_if_wrong: A classic social engineering tactic used, the sense of urgency at 'as quick as possible' and mismatched domain.

questions.text: You have just received an email with this following link, that seems tricky...
questions.explain_if_correct: Phished link catched!
questions.explain_if_wrong: Despite the safe padlock, this is actually not the legitimate link. 'https://myaccount.google.com' is the legitimate one.

questions.text: An another email that came with this link, let's check...
questions.explain_if_correct: Good spotting, no red flags here.
questions.explain_if_wrong: That is actually a safe link, a safe padlock and no typos, good to go.

questions.text: An email from Github about a two-factor authentication just came into your inbox, let's see...
questions.explain_if_correct: Nice catch, this email is good to go.
questions.explain_if_wrong: No visible red flags, the sender's domain is not mismatched, and also the links are secured, with no typos. All good.

questions.text: You receive a phone call from the Danish Police telling you, in English, that you're involved in a money laundering case, therefore they ask you for your personal credentials to avoid arrest. Is it Legitimate or Phish?
questions.explain_if_correct: Good job! The police never calls you randomly about this made-up scenarios, and not in English, but in the local language.
questions.explain_if_wrong: That's a phished call. The Danish Police would approach you first in their local language, and definitely not randomly, talking about a money laundering case.

questions.text: Your union in Denmark calls you, asking if you are interested in some workshops regarding some job application guidelines, as they see in their system you're due to resign from your working place. They first approach you in Danish, but then call is carried in English. Is it Legitimate or Phish?
questions.explain_if_correct: Yup, it is a legitimate call.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Worry not, this is a safe call here. They first approached you in the local language, and then they switched to English upon your request to carry on the conversation.

questions.text: You're in your lunch break and suddenly your phone rings. You pick up the call, and all you can hear is a robot-like voice saying 'Hi, we need to talk', and then it hangs up. A legitimate or phish call?
questions.explain_if_correct: Good catch! Bonus points if you didn't say anything, as phishers can actually record your voice.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Being called by a robotic-like voice is a huge red flag, as they can actually manipulate you into actually 'talking more' with them. Your voice also gets recorded for further attacks so be cautious.

questions.text: You receive a call from this following phone number: '(+45)3874740', but something feels phishy... do not copy this phone number by the way. For educational purposes only.
questions.explain_if_correct: Good catch! Typos in the phone number is a huge red flag.
questions.explain_if_wrong: That actually smells phishy. A danish phone number always has 8 numbers, but this one has only 7, clearly mistyped phone number. Always good to double check.

questions.text: You get a call from your brother telling that he has just been involved in a serious accident, and he's in an urgent need of a great amount of money for medical services. Is this legitimate, or does it feel like a phishing attempt?
questions.explain_if_correct: Good catch! This is the classical 'accident' phishing method.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Signs such as asking for huge amount of money and to be sent immediately are big red flags. Here you're dealing with the classical 'accident' phishing method.

questions.text: Your cousin initiates the phone call with you to tell that your aunt was involved in an accident and taken to the hospital. They say that they might need some financial support, but not for now, as all what is needed more is emotional support. Maybe true, maybe a phisher behind the scenes?
questions.explain_if_correct: That's a good one, nothing abnormal here.
questions.explain_if_wrong: In reality, there's no phisher right here, just your cousin. No signs of urgency are involved, just more of a emotional support that they need more than ever.

questions.text: A charity company is calling you to talk about their mission and objectives, and present their monthly fee, asking you if you're interested at the end. Remember that you met with them on the street and told you're interested, but preferred to be contacted about more information.
questions.explain_if_correct: Exactly, this is a legitimate call.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Not a phish here. You met the charity on the street, and communicated you wanted to know more about their objectives, so this was a solicited call. No sense of urgency either.

questions.text: You receive a call from a Danish phone number, you pick up and you're met by this sentence 'The Chinese Embassy...'. Any red flags here?
questions.explain_if_correct: We've just catched a phish call!
questions.explain_if_wrong: That's a trap, most probably used to record your voice to be used towards other targets. Danish phone number, getting unsolicited call from the chinese embassy, these don't come along together.

questions.text: You pick up a call that says you have just won a brand new blender. However, in order to claim the prize, you must pay a fee. Let's see if it is legitimate or not.
questions.explain_if_correct: A phish! It's this one, right here.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Auchie, in reality there was no brand new blender, but your information went bye-bye. Phishers make use of unbelievable scenarios to trick you.

questions.text: An another phone call on the way, with this phone number '(+45)29383920', everything seems fine, but it is marked as 'possible scam'. Don't copy the phone number, for educational purposes only.
questions.explain_if_correct: Exactly, a potential phish right here.
questions.explain_if_wrong: If a phone number is flagged as potential scam, there are high probabilities that it could actually be spam. That is why is a good practice to use spams filters.

questions.text: 'Beware, your account has been set to Inactive, so you will not be able to use it. Reactivate now.'
questions.explain_if_correct: Right on the spot! Despite the url looking safe, the grammatical error and the sense of urgency give it away.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Here we deal with grammar mispelling: 'Inactive, not 'inactive', the sense of urgency: 'reactivate now', and the dodgy domain.

questions.text: You get a SMS from PostNord saying 'Your order is ready for pick up, follow the steps to receive it.'
questions.explain_if_correct: The message here is in Danish, however the phone code and the phished link gives the suspicions away. Nice job!
questions.explain_if_wrong: The SMS is in danish, however the correct phone code would be +45, and the link will more likely to redirect you somewhere else.

questions.text: You get this following SMS about your parking account being temporarily due to absent payment, what do you think it is?
questions.explain_if_correct: This one is safe, it is normal to have your account paused if the payment is missing.
questions.explain_if_wrong: If the payment is missing, you'll be notified about your account being paused due to that, which is normal.

questions.text: 'Congratulations! You have won a free board with buckets and shots to the weekend. Come at least 4 people.'
questions.explain_if_correct: That is a legitimate one. There's a condition set to claim this prize.
questions.explain_if_wrong: There's a condition if you want to claim this prize, so you're safe with this one.

questions.text: 'TheYouBoys looking for job in the oven?' that's suspicious...
questions.explain_if_correct: Exactly, grammar mistakes and the random VAN number give it away.
questions.explain_if_wrong: That is the phishers' attempt to trick you with this job seeking scenario. Grammar mistakes and a random VAN number are clear red flags.

questions.text: 'Your package has arrived, but it requires processing of customs duties, fill out the form here.', a package I never ordered.
questions.explain_if_correct: That is a phish SMS, right here!
questions.explain_if_wrong: Asked for personal information in order to receive a package you never ordered, and not a trustworthy link? No.

questions.text: A SMS about a job application update, let's check it out, and maybe the email eventually. Is it legitimate or not?
questions.explain_if_correct: That's a legitimate one, if you applied for the job.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Just an update about an interview call, where they kindly ask you to check the email for further information, so nothing wrong here.

questions.text: 'The debt agency has sent you a Digital Post, log in here', a SMS from debt agency, weird.
questions.explain_if_correct: Yes! The phisher pretends to be someone from the Debt Agency, texting you with a fake replica of authentication page.
questions.explain_if_wrong: The link might take you to a fake authentication code, and it doesn't have a padlock, so clearly a phish here.

questions.text: 'You have received a new post from IDA. You can read your post by logging in to *provided link*. At the bottom of the page you can access the case number.'
questions.explain_if_correct: The union lets you know a post has been sent to your account, the padlock is there and the link is the real one, so all good.
questions.explain_if_wrong: The link has secure padlock, and it actually goes to the union's login page. No red flags here.

questions.text: 'We have received your shipment, but the custom duties are being charged. Please fill out the form.'
questions.explain_if_correct: Exactly, a potential phish right here. Despite the link's safe padlock, social engineering tactics are heavily present here.
questions.explain_if_wrong: Despite the link looking safe and having a padlock, remember that you're never asked to fill out a form to receive your order.
